title: Melinda Gates Commits $1 Billion to Advance Gender Equality in U.S.
text:
Text size

Melinda Gates, a champion of women’s rights around the world, is seeking to accelerate gender equality in the U.S. over the next decade.

“Equality can’t wait, and no one in a position to act should either,” Gates wrote in an op-ed for Time magazine on Tuesday, while announcing a $1 billion commitment “to expanding women’s power and influence.”

In 2015, Gates, 55, founded Pivotal Ventures, an investment and incubation company working to drive social progress for women and families. She also co-chairs the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, the world’s largest philanthropy, with her husband Bill Gates.

“This announcement is not a departure for Melinda—it’s the latest chapter in her long-standing commitment to gender equality,” a spokesperson at Pivotal Ventures tells Penta.

In her recent book, The Moment of Lift, Gates describes her conviction in the power and potential of gender equality in lifting up families, communities, and society at large.

In her op-ed, Gates outlines three priorities in achieving gender equality in the U.S., which is 208 years away, she says, citing data from the World Economic Forum.

The first priority is dismantling the barriers to women’s professional advancement. The second is fast-tracking women in sectors with outsized impact on society—such as technology, media, and public office. The third is mobilizing shareholders, consumers, and employees to amplify external pressure on companies and organizations in need of reform.

“It’s very exciting to see Melinda step up and talk about gender disparity, and make this large-scale investment,” says Debra Mesch, Eileen Lamb O’Gara chair in Women’s Philanthropy at the Indiana University Lilly Family School of Philanthropy.

“We’ve seen this happen in the philanthropic space, where women are making large-scale investments to really change the lives of women and girls,” she says. “Melinda is focusing on broadening that from philanthropy to the government sector and the private sector.”

Parallel to Pivotal Ventures’s large-scale investment in gender equality, Women Moving Millions is an example in the nonprofit sector “where women are hyper-agents who're using their wealth, through philanthropy, to really create social change,” Mesch says.

The New York-based organization established by Swanee Hunt, the founding director of the Women and Public Policy Program at the Kennedy School of Harvard University and a former U.S. Ambassador to Austria, and her sister Helen, has raised over $500 million for women’s and girls’ causes since its existence in 2007.

Gender equality has been chronically underfunded in the U.S. According to data Gates cited from Candid’s Foundation Directory Online, private donors give $9.27 to higher education and $4.85 to the arts for every $1 they give to women’s issues.

Among the U.S.’s high-net-worth population, about 20% donated to women’s and girls’ causes in 2017, with an average donation of just over $1,800 to these causes, according to the latest U.S. Trust Study of High Net Worth Philanthropy conducted by Lilly Family School of Philanthropy.

“One billion [dollars] is a lot of money, but I also recognize that it’s only a small fraction of what’s necessary,” Gates says. “That’s why I hope the financial commitment I’m making today is seen as both a vote of confidence in the experts and advocates who are already working on these issues—and an invitation for others to join the cause and make commitments of their own.”
description: The money will go toward fast-tracking women in technology, media, and politics, among other goals
